overview: Malachi, the final Old Testament book, addresses a spiritually apathetic post-exilic community. Through a dialogue format, God confronts their half-hearted worship and promises a coming messenger to prepare the way.

verses.text: Bring the full tithe into the storehouse, that there may be food in my house. And thereby put me to the test, says the LORD of hosts, if I will not open the windows of heaven for you and pour down for you a blessing until there is no more need.
But for you who fear my name, the sun of righteousness shall rise with healing in its wings.
Behold, I send my messenger, and he will prepare the way before me. And the Lord whom you seek will suddenly come to his temple.

passages.title: The Coming Messenger
passages.summary: God promises to send a messenger to prepare the way—fulfilled in John the Baptist—before the Lord Himself comes.

passages.title: Elijah's Return
passages.summary: The final Old Testament words promise Elijah will come before the great day of the LORD—fulfilled in John the Baptist.

facts.text: Malachi ends the Old Testament, and 400 years of prophetic silence follow until John the Baptist—the messenger promised here.
Jesus confirmed that John the Baptist was the 'Elijah' Malachi promised (Matthew 11:14).
Malachi uses a question-and-answer format throughout, with the people challenging God and God responding.
Malachi 3:10 is the only place in Scripture where God invites people to 'test' Him.

figures.name: Malachi
figures.description: The final Old Testament prophet whose name means 'my messenger.' He prepared Israel for the long wait until John the Baptist.

videos.title: Malachi Overview
videos.description: The Bible Project explores the Old Testament's final book and its promise of a coming messenger.
